name: Python.org
tooltip: Home of Python. I strongly recommend downloading the Anaconda distribution if you're interested in data science.

name: Anaconda
tooltip: The Anaconda distribution contains many of the necessary packages for data analysis and data science. If working from the comand line you can use commands such as 'conda install pandas'.

name: Conda Package List
tooltip: A list of the default packages that comes with the Conda Python distribution.

name: Jupyter Notebook
tooltip: Jupyter Notebooks (formerly iPython) is a browser-based IDE that is the standard for creating reproducible reports in Python. It also works with R and Julia but has its roots in Python.

name: NumPy
tooltip: NumPy is the base package for working with statistics and arrays in Python. Many of the other Python data analysis packages depend on NumPy.

name: SciPy
tooltip: SciPy extends NumPy by adding a collection of algorithms and high-level commands for manipulating and visualizing data.

name: Pandas
tooltip: Pandas makes working with data frames easy. It is very similar to dplyr in R.

name: Matplotlib
tooltip: Matplotlib is the base package for computing graphs in Python.

name: Seaborn
tooltip: Seaborn extends matplotlib to create aesthetical visualizations and for enhanced control of plot features.

name: Scikit Learn
tooltip: Scikit Learn implements many of the machine learning algorithms in Python. It is very similar to caret in R.

name: Theano
tooltip: Theano is similar to NumPy except built for speed. Using the computer's GPU
link: Theano is optimized to obtain speeds approaching C.

name: Natural Language Toolkit (NLTK)
tooltip: NLTK provides a suite of text processing libraries for classification + tokenization + stemming + tagging + parsing text. The website also has a link to a book written by NTLK's authors.
